ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Quantum well intermixing of multiple quantum wells on InP by argon plasma bombardment and the sputtered-SiO2 film

Affiliation.OrgName: National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences

OrgAddress.Street: No. 415 Chien Kung Rd., Sanmin Dist.

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A quantum well intermixing process combining inductively-coupled-plasma reactive ion etching (ICP-RIE) and SiO2 sputtering film was investigated for the InGaAsP and InGaAlAs multi-quantum wells (MQWs). Optimal distance is 300-nm-thick for InGaAsP and of 200-nm-thick for InGaAlAs. Between MQWs and the upper cladding by ICP-RIE and bombardment, covering the 300-nm-thick sputtered SiO2 using rapid thermal annealer (RTA) processing resulted in a band-gap blue-shift of 90 nm for InGaAsP and of 60 nm for InGaAlAs.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Photonic integrated circuits (PICs) often require the integration of passive and active sections on an n-type InP substrate containing multiple quantum wells (MQWs). MQW structures are beneficial for optoelectronic devices such as lasers (LDs), modulators and filters used in 1.55-μm optical communications [1, 2]. Quantum well intermixing (QWI) techniques have attracted a lot of attention because these methods are important for PICs and optoelectronic integrated circuits (OEICs) [3–5]. To fabricate a photonic integrated device, the band-gap energy of the passive section needs to be higher than that of the active section. Selective etching and re-growth processes are used to create different band-gap energies on a semiconductor chip, but these methods have complicated procedures. Using QWI system, however, is much more cost effective and allows the butt joint to perfectly align on a chip. QWI is a powerful technique for monolithic integrated optoelectronic devices of varying functionalities on a single wafer and it allows a post-growth modification of an absorption edge. QWI can create regions with different band gaps by using post-growth procedures such as impurity-induced disordering (IID) [6], ion-implantation-enhanced interdiffusion (IIEI) [7], laser-induced disordering [8] and impurity-free vacancy diffusion (IFVD) [9, 10].

By using argon plasma bombardment and dry etching to the optimal depth, more point defects are induced into the i-layer. Through thermal treatment under a higher temperature and annealing, the continuous deposition of a 300-nm-thick sputtered-SiO2 capping layer is also very useful for enhancing the QWI effect. The point defects induced by argon plasma and atomic bombardment [3–5] play a key role in QWI, which with the joint IFVD technique and the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer, can assist in accelerating the out-diffusion of Ga into the capping layer. This leads to the injection of Ga vacancies into the quantum wells; therefore, the group III vacancies generated in QW region promote the interdiffusion between quantum wells and barriers.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para:
One of the samples was of p-i-n structure grown on n-type InP substrate by metal organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). This sample was separated by 4.2-nm-thick In0.57Ga0.43As0.64P0.36 barriers and consisted of three 8.4-nm-thick In0.77Ga0.23As0.79P0.21 quantum wells emitting wavelength at 1568 nm. The epi-layer sequence is depicted in Table 1. Another sample was of a p-i-n structure grown on n-type InP substrate through solid-source molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). This sample, separated by 10-nm-thick In0.53Ga0.26Al0.21As barriers, consisted of three 9-nm-thick In0.53Ga0.47As quantum wells emitting wavelength at 1608 nm. The epi-layer sequence is depicted in Table 2.

The Plasmalab System 100 is an argon plasma source generator of inductively-coupled-plasma reactive ion etching (ICPRIE) built by Oxford Instruments. The ICPRIE system used in these experiments played an important role for argon plasma dry etching and enhanced bombardment [3–5]. The ICPRIE conditions for these experiments were set for an Ar flow rate of 90 sccm, a working pressure of 30 mtorr, an RF power of 200 watt, and an ICP power of 300 watt at a substrate temperature of 180 °C. The etching rate for the epi-layer is 175 (nm/min) by MOCVD wafer and 200 (nm/min) by MBE wafer. After Ar plasma exposure, a 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer was sputtered upon the wafers [9, 10]. These samples were treated by ICPRIE without a 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer on the MBE wafers. Using a solution (H3PO4:H2O2:H2O=1:2:37) wet etching to replace the ICP-RIE dry etching role, a 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer was sputtered upon the MBE wafers. The treated samples were annealed in a rapid thermal annealer (RTA) at different temperatures of 700, 750 and 800 ∘C for 1 minute in N2 gas at a flow rate of 100 sccm. The samples were then sandwiched between two fresh pieces of GaAs proximity caps and were used to provide an arsenic over-pressure environment during the annealing process. After the completion of these experiments, the photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the wafers were measured at room temperature.

Section2.Heading: In0.77Ga0.23As0.79P0.21/In0.57Ga0.43As0.64P0.36 samples were grown by MOCVD system
Section2.Para:
The graphs in Fig. 1 display the PL spectra of In0.77Ga0.23As0.79P0.21/In0.57Ga0.43As0.64P0.36 MQWs samples measured at room temperature. The first graph (a) shows the data of a sample that was annealed in a RTA. Graph (b) depicts a PL spectra of a sample treated with 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer by plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) with a RTA, while graph (c) shows the spectra of a 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer by sputter with a RTA. The final graph (d) shows the spectra of a sample after Ar plasma exposure by ICPRIE covering 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer by sputter with a RTA. The samples were annealed at different temperatures of 700, 750 and 800 ∘C. The PL peak of the as-grown sample was measured at 1568 nm. Because the samples were only annealed, the PL spectra in Fig. 1(a) had a thermal shift with a blue-shift of 8 nm. When depositing a 300-nm-thick SiO2 film on wafers through PECVD at different annealing temperatures of 700, 750 and 800 °C for 1 minute, the blue-shift of the wavelength in Fig. 1(b) was only 2 nm. In Fig. 1(c), as the only sputtered 300-nm-thick SiO2 capping layer, a maximum blue-shift wavelength of 62 nm at the annealing temperature of 800 °C for 1 minute. After Ar plasma bombardment and dry etching by ICPRIE was treated at different times of 1, 3, 4 and 6 minutes with the sputtered 300-nm SiO2, the maximum blue-shift of the wavelength in Fig. 1(d) was 90 nm under the treated time of 4 minutes by ICPRIE with the annealing temperature of 800 °C for 1 minute. The amount of blue-shift was determined from the treated time by ICP-RIE. The samples from Fig. 2 were treated under different times of 1, 3, 4 and 6 minutes through ICPRIE with different annealing temperatures of 700, 750 and 800 °C for 1 minute. The optimal time is 4 min by ICPRIE and the optimal distance is 300 nm between MQWs and the upper cladding.
Fig. 1
(a) Only RTA at different temperatures of 700, 750 and 800 ∘C for 1 minute in N2 gas at a flow rate of 100 sccm; (b) 300-nm-thick SiO2 by PECVD and RTA; (c) 300-nm-thick sputtered SiO2 and RTA; (d) PL spectra of the sample In0.77Ga0.23As0.79P0.21/In0.57Ga0.43As0.64P0.36 MQWs under different ICP-RIE times and the same annealing temperature of 800 ∘C for 1 minute
Fig. 2
Blue-shift vs. annealing temperature under different ICP-RIE times

The argon plasma in ICPRIE may produce sufficient point defects to promote QWI in MQWs samples and combine the porous sputtered-SiO2 layer (IFVD) making use of the diffusion of point defects. For example, group III vacancies were created during the deposition of sputtered-silica film by thermal treatment. As the distance between MQWs and the upper cladding layer is reduced to 300 nm, more than group III vacancies can diffuse out from MQWs to the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer. From here we can determine the amount of wavelength blue-shifting from PL measurements at room temperature. At an annealing temperature of 800 °C, a significant diffusion of atomic species occurs, such that the wavelength blues-shifting results in an interdiffusion of the well and barrier alloys. As atoms and vacancies interdiffuse in the active region, the boundary between QWs and barriers becomes imperceptible.

In order to visualize the change in MQWs composition after the QWI process, the double-crystal X-ray diffractometer (DCXRD) measurement was used [11]; the measured composition of QWs and barriers is shown in Fig. 3. When comparing the composition of QW (In0.77Ga0.23As0.79P0.21) before and after the QWI process, the lattice arrangement before the QWI sample was not in agreement with that after the QWI.
Fig. 3
DCXRD spectra of the InGaAsP as-grown and the 90-nm-blueshifting samples

Section2.Heading: In0.53Ga0.47As/In0.53Ga0.26Al0.21As MQW samples were grown by MBE system
Section2.Para:
The same experiment was conducted on the In0.53Ga0.47As/In0.53Ga0.26Al0.21As MQWs samples by MBE system. The PL peak of the as-grown sample was measured at 1608 nm. After Ar+ plasma bombardment and dry etching by ICPRIE was treated at different times of 4, 6, 7, 8 and 8.5 minutes with the sputtered 300-nm-thick SiO2, the maximum blue-shift of the wavelength in Fig. 4(a) was 60 nm at the temperature of 700 °C for 1 minute. The amount of blue-shift was also determined from the treated time by ICP-RIE. As the distance between MQWs and the upper cladding layer was reduced, more Ga atoms out-diffused into the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer, which led to the injection of Ga vacancies into QW structure. This resulted in the wavelength blue-shifting from PL measurements at room temperature. This process caused an increase in the band-gap energy, namely an inter-diffusion of the well and barrier alloys. The PL peak of the maximum wavelength blue-shift was not as sharp as of the as-grown one. When the time of Ar+ plasma bombardment by ICP-RIE was increased to 8.5 min, the maximum blue-shift of the wavelength in Fig. 4(a) was reduced to 42 nm. As the distance between MQWs and the upper cladding layer became too close, Ar+ plasma bombardment by ICP-RIE damaged the MQWs intermixing region, therefore causing the amount of blue-shift to be reduced. The samples from Fig. 4(b) were treated under different times of 4, 6, 7, 8 and 8.5 minutes by ICP-RIE with different annealing temperatures 700, 750 and 800 °C for 1 minute. For the In0.53Ga0.47As/In0.53Ga0.26Al0.21As MQWs structure, the optimal time is 8 min by ICP-RIE and the optimal distance of 200 nm between MQWs and the upper cladding.
Fig. 4
(a) PL spectra at room temperature of the sample In0.53Ga0.47As/In0.53Ga0.26Al0.21As MQWs under different ICP-RIE times and the same annealing temperature of 700 ∘C for 1 minute in N2 gas at a flow rate of 100 sccm. (b) Blue-shift vs. annealing temperature under different ICP-RIE times

In this experiment, we investigated the influence of the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer and Ar+ plasma bombardment by ICPRIE under the QWI process. First, the samples were etched and bombarded by ICPRIE for 8 min without the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer at annealing temperatures of 700 and 750 °C. The maximum blue-shift of wavelength in Fig. 5(a) was only 20 nm at the annealing temperature of 700 °C for 1 min. Comparing Fig. 4(a) with Fig. 5(a), the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer provided an extra amount of blue-shift during the QWI process. The out-diffusion of group III atoms into the porous sputtered-SiO2 capping layer resulted in an increase of vacancies near the interface surface, by which the group V atoms diffused into MQWs region at the annealing temperatures of 700 and 750 °C. Second, wet etching replaced ICP-RIE dry etching. The samples were only etched by a H3PO4 solution (H3PO4:H2O2:H2O=1:2:37) to the distance of 200 nm between MQWs and the upper cladding layer with the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer from Fig. 5(b). The amount of blue-shift was only 18 nm at the annealing temperature of 700 °C for 1 minute. Comparing Fig. 4(a) with Fig. 5(b), the distance between MQWs and the upper cladding layer by wet etching and dry etching was the same. Extra amount of vacancies was generated under the treated samples by ICP-RIE, which led to more diffusion under QWI process.
Fig. 5
(a) PL spectra by ICP-RIE for 8 min without SiO2 capping layer under the annealing temperature of 700 and 750 ∘C; (b) PL spectra of InGaAlAs samples using H3PO4 solution wet etching to replace ICP-RIE dry etching

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: The characterization of Ar+ plasma bombardment by joint IFVD technique with the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer induced QWI were investigated for In0.77Ga0.23As0.79P0.21/In0.57Ga0.43As0.64P0.36 MQWs structure by MOCVD and In0.53Ga0.47As/In0.53Ga0.26Al0.21As MQWs structure by MBE. Three main factors contributed to the influence of the QWI process. First, the optimal thickness between MQWs and the upper cladding layer was 200 nm for InGaAlAs material and 300 nm for InGaAsP material by ICP-RIE. The majority of point defects were generated in this factor. Second, the enhanced defects were assisted by atomic bombardment under a deposited porous SiO2 film. Third, atoms and defects obtained sufficient energy to diffuse under higher annealing temperature. Samples with the Ar+ bombardment and the jointed IFVD technique had a higher degree of intermixing than the Ar+ bombardment alone or the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer under RTA treatment. This is attributed to the fact that the upper cladding layer is too thick to generate the point defects and thermal expansion effect; therefore, the maximum blue-shift of wavelength of 60 nm for InGaAlAs material and of 90 nm for InGaAsP material using Ar+ plasma bombardment with the sputtered-SiO2 capping layer has been achieved under the RTA treatment. This behavior is very useful for re-growth and fabrication of PICs.
